column2: how are npm modules going to work when there are many different yearly versions of javascript? __eou__
protometa: there is theenginesproperty ( [<-LINK->] ) to warn about compatibility __eou__
ewnd9: engines could work  __eou__

but it doesn't seem to be used much. I'm also thinking about the use of npm for frontend modules. It seems like we are going to need to have better tracking of javascript version or we'll be in javascript version hell, or be stuck with publishing only es5 modules forever. __eou__

protometa: I'm fine with es5 . But as an example of a variation - somereact-nativemodules are published as is and if you need to use them in other environments you need to use only single presetbabel-preset-react-native __eou__

ewnd9: that works if you know a specific module or set of modules is pure es6 or es7 but seems like we need a more general solution for module consumers to know which version of javascript a module uses. __eou__
rather than making it a concern of newer modules to covert for older consumers the older consumers could just convert newer modules that they wish to use. __eou__
then we could all publish pure es7 modules and a platform that can run es7 isn't stuck with es5. __eou__

Hi guys. I am trying to combine angular 2 with .net mvc 5 and I seem to lack some basic understanding here regarding npm. I have so far only used angular2 combined with meteor so I didn't have to deal with this things...Do I need to have node.js on the server for deployment? Like locally in development I just install my packages with npm install etc. in node_modules. But for deployment I don't want to have node.js there, can I just bundle node_modules somehow or how does it work? __eou__

bergben: I would assume where you are deploying would have node installed - for example on Heroku you provide build instructions and your package.json file and it does the rest.  I believe digital ocean works the same way.  I have not done it in a while so I am recalling this from memory __eou__
bergben: you need node at build time, and you should be deploying an archived tarball to production __eou__

I understand I need it at build time, but I would rather build it beforehand and then deploy the build. By now I am thinking about bundling the whole node_modules using [<-LINK->] and then just include that file... Do you think that would work? Or how do you mean "deploying an archived tarball", how would I do that@ljharb?@maxwellsmart84I know how it works for Heorku, unfortunately this project is for a company for a client on a custom server and communicating them to install node.js and npm then do npm install etc. just makes it complicated for them and should be avoided at all costs __eou__
I appreciate your help by the way guys@ljharband@maxwellsmart84 __eou__
bergben: are you deploying to a UNIX env? __eou__

Actually I am not even the one deploying so I don't even know that, I just know it should be as easy as possible and therefore the frontend stuff should just be bundled and included and good to go. No prior extra work on the server needed, so it shouldn't even matter which server I deploy to... __eou__
yeah that is tricky __eou__
[<-LINK->]  __eou__
i found that - so its possible to run package manager through a proxy - just not sure if its your solution __eou__

I actually got it runnng using rollupjs. It gets an entry point and follows up all the import statements and creates a minified bundle out of that. This is freaking awesome. All I have to do in production now is include one single javascript file __eou__
maxwellsmart84: Thanks though, I appreciate your effort! __eou__
bergben: you're definitely supposed to build, tar up the build, and then deploy that archive later __eou__
bergben: which means you only need node to make the build. you don't need it in production at all, unless you're using a node service __eou__

So I've been digging around, and I can't seem to find a planned features roadmap, so my question is, when is async/await supposed to drop? __eou__
palodequeso: async/await is supposed to land in v8 LTS in march, node.js won\'t get it right away, though it\'s already available behind the "--harmony" flag in node 7 __eou__
ah, interesting, I didn't know it was available behind harmony, but March then, sweet __eou__
I'll plan rewrites accordingly haha __eou__
don't use the harmony flag ever __eou__
the async/await implementation behind the harmony flag has a ton of memory leaks and bugs __eou__
the harmony flag is for broken features - if it was reliable in production, it'd be unflagged. __eou__
Harmony is for not-quite-production-ready features, horribly broken features get their own separate flags. It does have a bunch of memory leaks and bugs though, so don't use itin production. __eou__
production-ready isn\'t a spectrum __eou__
either way, the harmony flags are for testing v8. they're not meant for production use, and you're a bad person if you use them. __eou__
